thread.title: The Sydney property fever is passing - but slowly
thread.title_full: The Sydney property fever is passing - but slowly | afr.com

author: Robert Harley
title: The Sydney property fever is passing - but slowly
text:
It is only one month. And there is no one catalyst that will bring the Sydney boom to an end. There is not an interest rate rise, or slowing employment growth or quieter offshore buying. Dallas Kilponen Sydney has been the fever capital. Reserve Bank governor Glenn Stevens, in his Tuesday statement on interest rates, is not calling the end to the fever. "Dwelling prices continue to rise strongly in Sydney," he said.
It is only one month. And there is no one catalyst that will bring the Sydney boom to an end. There is not an interest rate rise, or slowing employment growth or quieter offshore buying.
So yes there will be more runaway auctions. And there will be more near sell-out off-the-plan apartment releases like the $380 million worth of apartments sold by Crown on the weekend at Green Square.
Restrained affairs But I think there will be fewer and fewer of those incendiary events. More and more auctions will be restrained affairs as the buyers and sellers are dragged together.
"With no further movement in interest rates anticipated and the latest crackdown by APRA on investors now being passed on by banks, the level of optimism in the market seems to have peaked", BIS Shrapnel associate director, Kim Hawtrey says.
He is also predicting that the national dwelling approvals have peaked.
Even as the fever subsides, the demand for housing in Sydney remains. Many can see solid demand, at current prices, for several years.
Stockland's chief executive, Mark Steinert, is confident that the market is only half way through the traditional seven or eight year housing cycle.
Another developer Toga Group's chief executive, development and construction, Fabrizio Perilli said the demand was still strong but the pricing was more realistic ."We are not seeing double-digit growth anymore," he told The Australian Financial Review this week.
